Add an extra widget to before footer widget area on Genesis Framework

Jane James · October 14, 2020 · 2 Comments

Facebook0Tweet0LinkedIn0


One of the things I love about Genesis framework is the use of widget areas.

Widget areas allow the user to easily change content within different areas of their website, with a plethora of options from built in and third party plugins. If your client is wanting a wordpress site setup that they or their marketing person will easily be able to manage themselves, then using widget areas only for their content is the best way to do it, in my opinion.

A client project I have been working on for Megan Jordan Celebrant required an additional widget area. Unknowingly, she describe the area correctly when she said “I’d like an instagram feed to appear before the footer.”

I laughed and said “Sure, you need a before footer widget area.”

Here’s how I did it:

Step 1.

First, I’m going to check the Genesis Visual Hook guide to find the correct action hook to place my widget. I’ve mapped it on the page and I am going to use the action hook genesis_before_footer which will ensure any content placed within the widget will appear right before the page footer.

Step 2.

Next we need to declare the widget area in our child themes functions.php file. Now I’ve used naming conventions that are specific to my client, but you can replace the id’s, names and description to match your project.

Here’s the code:

Step 3.

Next, we need to position the widget to the before footer widget area. This is the part where we add the action hook genesis_before_footer, that “hooks in” the widget area to the before footer location.

Step 4.

Now we have added the above code to our functions.php file, If you log into the front end and click on the widgets area, the widget and description are displayed as so:

Step 5.

Now, when I add the widget to my before_footer_widget_area, I have selected Spotlight Instagram Feed which is an awesome plugin that connects to your client’s instagram page to show the latest posts. It’s follow buttons are load more buttons are customisable with CSS, included in the free version. You can see the result below.

And that’s it! If you found this article helpful, or have questions please contact me, tweet me or comment.
